newsitem.title: ALBANIA: Albanians want international help to recover dead.
newsitem.headline: Albanians want international help to recover dead.

text.p: Albanians in the rebel-held southern port of Vlore put aside their guns on Monday for a rally to commemorate the victims of a tragic shipping accident and to call for international help to recover the bodies.

Rally organisers said an estimated 103 people drowned a month ago when a ship carrying Albanians fleeing the troubled Balkan state collided with an Italian navy frigate 30 miles off Brindisi in southern Italy and sank.

"We're asking all the world's humanitarian organisations to recover the bodies so our relatives can rest in peace in their homeland," Aferdita Bani, a spokeswoman for a group of victims' relatives, told 5,000 people gathered in the main square.
"This would be a consolation for us, the families, so we can have a place where we can go to talk to them."

Vlore residents called on Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi, who visited the grief-stricken town on April 13, to honour his pledge to help recover the bodies and to investigate the accident that many blame on the Italian boat.

After a minute's silence, the victims' widows and mothers, dressed in black and carrying lit candles, led the procession along Vlore's palm-lined boulevard, to the entrance of the port. Only one gunman was seen among the crowd.

Over the past week 850 Italian and Greek soldiers, part of a multi-national force assigned to Albania to oversee aid deliveries, have secured the port, blocking thousands of Albanians who have been trying to escape the violent unrest.
Over 13,000 illegal refugees have fled by ship to Italy or into neighbouring Greece since Albanians took to the streets, angered by the loss of savings in fraudulent investment funds.
Rebels armed with guns looted from state arsenals blame President Sali Berisha for the funds disaster and have taken control of much of southern Albania.

On Sunday Italian authorities at Barletta rescued 517 Albanians who were crammed into a vessel built for no more than 50 people. The ship had taken 26 hours to cross the Adriatic, setting sail from Shengjin near Shkoder in northern Albania.

Friends and relatives of the victims of last month's tragedy were in tears, some crying hysterically, other fainting, as they walked along a jetty, clutching white lilies and red roses that they threw out to sea for the dead.

Thirty friends of victim Fiqiri Sula, a 30-year-old engineer, were among the mourners to pay their respects to their friend and his five relatives, including a two-year-old nephew, who died in the tragedy.
Work colleague Maksim Beta said Sula and his relatives had paid 800,000 Lek ($500) each for passage on the ship.
"We had been friends for five years. He was a good man. It was tragic that this was his fate," Beta told Reuters.
"But a month has passed and nothing has been done to recover the bodies. We want action."
As distraught relatives were led away from the jetty, the lone gunman stood on the end of the pier and fired a volley of shots into the air to bid farewell to the victims.
Heavily armed Italian soldiers watched from a distance but made no move. The only police in Vlore have been relegated to directing traffic.
"The people are in control in this town and this is not going to change in the near future," Lieutenant Commander Stefano Cappellaro told Reuters.
